001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004import squidpony.annotation.Beta;
005
006import java.util.ArrayList;
007import java.util.Collection;
008import java.util.Iterator;
009import java.util.SortedSet;
010
011/**
012 * An ordered bidirectional map-like data structure, with "bundles" of unique E1 (Element type 1) keys and unique E2
013 * (Element type 2) keys updated together like a map that can be queried by E1 key bundles, E2 key bundles, or int
014 * indices, as well as like a multimap that can be queried by lone E1 or E2 keys. A bundle can be specified as a
015 * Collection of E1 or E2 values, an array of E1 or E2 values, or in two parts as either of the above given to a
016 * BundleBiMap method along with an int array that can represent variations on keys (e.g. some quantity for an E1 or E2
017 * value that permits different amounts to be passed with the unique element values to it yield a different E2 bundle
018 * for, say, 1 Foo and 1 Bar vs. 2 Foo and 3 Bar). This allows an intended purpose for this class as a way to describe
019 * crafting recipes that may need various amounts of an item to be mixed in and for multiple items with their own
020 * quantities to be produced, and since the quantities are optional, it can still be used to group multiple E1 keys with
021 * multiple E2 keys. The multimap property allows you to use an E1 or E2 element key to get all of the E2 or E1 keys
022 * that are associated with a bundle that contains that E1 or E2 key.
023 * <br>
024 * Does not implement any interfaces that you would expect for a data structure, because almost every method it has
025 * needs to specify whether it applies to E1 or E2 items, or otherwise doesn't fit a normal Collection-like interface's
026 * requirements.
027 * <br>
028 * Closely related to BundleBiMap, Arrangement, K2, and K2V1 in implementation.
029 * <br>
030 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/26/2017.
031 */
032@Beta
033public class BundleBundleBiMap<E1, E2>
034{
035    private Arrangement<E1> elements1;
036    private Arrangement<E2> elements2;
037    private K2<int[][], int[][]> bm;
038    private ArrayList<IntVLA> mm1, mm2;
039
040    /**
041     * Constructs an empty BundleBiMap.
042     */
043    public BundleBundleBiMap()
044    {
045        this(Arrangement.DEFAULT_INITIAL_SIZE, Arrangement.DEFAULT_LOAD_FACTOR);
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * Constructs a BundleBiMap with the expected number of indices to hold (the number of bundles and number of E2 items
050     * is always the same, and this will be more efficient if expected is greater than that number).
051     * @param expected how many bundle-to-single pairings this is expected to hold
052     */
053    public BundleBundleBiMap(int expected)
054    {
055        this(expected, Arrangement.DEFAULT_LOAD_FACTOR);
056    }
057
058    /**
059     * Constructs a BundleBiMap with the expected number of indices to hold (the number of bundles and number of E2 items
060     * is always the same, and this will be more efficient if expected is greater than that number) and the load factor
061     * to use, between 0.1f and 0.8f usually (using load factors higher than 0.8f can cause problems).
062     * @param expected the amount of indices (the count of bundles is the same as the count of E2 items) this should hold
063     * @param f the load factor, probably between 0.1f and 0.8f
064     */
065    public BundleBundleBiMap(int expected, float f)
066    {
067        elements1 = new Arrangement<>(expected, f);
068        elements2 = new Arrangement<>(expected, f);
069        bm = new K2<>(expected, f, CrossHash.int2DHasher, CrossHash.int2DHasher);
070        mm1 = new ArrayList<>(expected * 4);
071        mm2 = new ArrayList<>(expected * 4);
072    }
073
074
075    /**
076     * Constructs a BundleBiMap using another BundleBiMap to copy.
077     * @param other the other BundleBiMap to copy
078     */
079    public BundleBundleBiMap(BundleBundleBiMap<E1, E2> other)
080    {
081        if(other == null)
082        {
083            elements1 = new Arrangement<>(64, 0.75f);
084            elements2 = new Arrangement<>(64, 0.75f);
085            bm = new K2<>(16, 0.75f, CrossHash.int2DHasher, CrossHash.int2DHasher);
086            mm1 = new ArrayList<>(64);
087            mm2 = new ArrayList<>(64);
088        }
089        else
090        {
091            elements1 = new Arrangement<>(other.elements1);
092            elements2 = new Arrangement<>(other.elements2);
093            bm = new K2<>(other.bm);
094            mm1 = new ArrayList<>(other.mm1);
095            mm2 = new ArrayList<>(other.mm2);
096        }
097    }
098
099    /**
100     * Returns true if this contains the E1, element, in any of its bundles of E1 keys.
101     * @param element the E1 to check the presence of in all bundles
102     * @return true if element is present in this; false otherwise
103     */
104    public boolean containsElement1(E1 element) { return elements1.containsKey(element); }
105    /**
106     * Returns true if this contains the E2, element, in its collection of E2 items.
107     * @param element the E2 to check the presence of
108     * @return true if element is present in this; false otherwise
109     */
110    public boolean containsElement2(E2 element) { return elements2.containsKey(element); }
111
112    /**
113     * Returns true if index is between 0 (inclusive) and {@link #size()} (exclusive), or false otherwise.
114     * @param index the index to check
115     * @return true if index is a valid index in the ordering of this BundleBiMap
116     */
117    public boolean containsIndex(int index) { return index >= 0 && index < bm.size(); }
118
119    /**
120     * Gets a random E1 from this BundleBiMap's individual elements1 using the given IRNG.
121     * @param random generates a random index to get an E1 with
122     * @return a randomly chosen E1, or null if this is empty
123     */
124    public E1 randomElement1(IRNG random)
125    {
126        return elements1.randomKey(random);
127    }
128
129    /**
130     * Gets a random E2 from this BundleBiMap using the given IRNG.
131     * @param random generates a random index to get a E2 with
132     * @return a randomly chosen E2, or null if this is empty
133     */
134    public E2 randomElement2(IRNG random)
135    {
136        return elements2.randomKey(random);
137    }
138
139    /**
140     * Adds a bundle of E1 keys and a E2 key at the same point in the ordering (the end) to this BundleBiMap. Neither
141     * parameter can be present in this collection before this is called.
142     * @param e1 an array of E1 keys to add; the array cannot already be present, nor can it be null
143     * @param e2 an array of E2 keys to add; the array cannot already be present, nor can it be null
144     * @return true if this collection changed as e1 result of this call
145     */
146    public boolean put(E1[] e1, E2[] e2)
147    {
148        if(e1 == null || e2 == null) return false;
149        int len = elements1.size;
150        elements1.putAll(e1);
151        for (int i = len; i < elements1.size; i++) {
152            mm1.add(new IntVLA(4));
153        }
154        len = elements2.size;
155        elements2.putAll(e2);
156        for (int i = len; i < elements2.size; i++) {
157            mm2.add(new IntVLA(4));
158        }
159        int[][] bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)};
160        int[][] bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2)};
161        if(!bm.put(bundle1, bundle2))
162            return false;
163        len = e1.length;
164        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
165            mm1.get(bundle1[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
166        }
167        len = e2.length;
168        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
169            mm2.get(bundle2[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
170        }
171        return true;
172    }
173    /**
174     * Adds a bundle of E1 keys, mixed with an int array of variations, and a E2 key at the same point in the ordering
175     * (the end) to this BundleBiMap. Neither the E2 key nor the bundle (effectively, the pair of e1 and variation) can be
176     * present in this collection before this is called.
177     * @param e1 an array of E1 keys to add; the array cannot already have been inserted with an equivalent variation, nor can it be null
178     * @param variation1 an int array that can be used to make a different version of e1, i.e. the same things at different quantities; cannot be null
179     * @param e2 an array of E2 keys to add; the array cannot already have been inserted with an equivalent variation, nor can it be null
180     * @param variation2 an int array that can be used to make a different version of e2, i.e. the same things at different quantities; cannot be null
181     * @return true if this collection changed as e1 result of this call
182     */
183    public boolean put(E1[] e1, int[] variation1, E2[] e2, int[] variation2)
184    {
185        if(e1 == null || e2 == null) return false;
186        int len = elements1.size;
187        elements1.putAll(e1);
188        for (int i = len; i < elements1.size; i++) {
189            mm1.add(new IntVLA(4));
190        }
191        len = elements2.size;
192        elements2.putAll(e2);
193        for (int i = len; i < elements2.size; i++) {
194            mm2.add(new IntVLA(4));
195        }
196        int[][] bundle1, bundle2;
197        if(variation1 == null)
198            bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)};
199        else
200            bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1), variation1};
201        if(variation2 == null)
202            bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2)};
203        else
204            bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2), variation2};
205        if(!bm.put(bundle1, bundle2))
206            return false;
207        len = e1.length;
208        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
209            mm1.get(bundle1[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
210        }
211        len = e2.length;
212        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
213            mm2.get(bundle2[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
214        }
215        return true;
216    }
217    /**
218     * Adds a bundle of E1 keys and a E2 key at the same point in the ordering (the end) to this BundleBiMap. Neither
219     * parameter can be present in this collection before this is called.
220     * @param e1 a Collection of E1 keys to add; the contents cannot already be present, nor can it be null
221     * @param e2 a Collection of E2 keys to add; the contents cannot already be present, nor can it be null
222     * @return true if this collection changed as a result of this call
223     */
224    public boolean put(Collection<? extends E1> e1, Collection<? extends E2> e2)
225    {
226        if(e1 == null || e2 == null) return false;
227        int len = elements1.size;
228        elements1.putAll(e1);
229        for (int i = len; i < elements1.size; i++) {
230            mm1.add(new IntVLA(4));
231        }
232        len = elements2.size;
233        elements2.putAll(e2);
234        for (int i = len; i < elements2.size; i++) {
235            mm2.add(new IntVLA(4));
236        }
237        int[][] bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)};
238        int[][] bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2)};
239        if(!bm.put(bundle1, bundle2))
240            return false;
241        len = e1.size();
242        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
243            mm1.get(bundle1[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
244        }
245        len = e2.size();
246        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
247            mm2.get(bundle2[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
248        }
249        return true;
250
251    }
252    /**
253     * Adds a bundle of E1 keys, mixed with an int array of variations, and a bundle of E2 keys at the same point in the
254     * ordering (the end) to this BundleBiMap. Neither the E1 bundle nor E2 bundle (effectively, the pair of element
255     * collection and variation) can be present in this collection before this is called.
256     * @param e1 a Collection of E1 keys to add; the Collection cannot already have been inserted with an equivalent variation, nor can it be null
257     * @param variation1 an int array that can be used to make a different version of e1, i.e. the same things at different quantities; cannot be null
258     * @param e2 a Collection of E2 keys to add; the Collection cannot already have been inserted with an equivalent variation, nor can it be null
259     * @param variation2 an int array that can be used to make a different version of e2, i.e. the same things at different quantities; cannot be null
260     * @return true if this collection changed as a result of this call
261     */
262    public boolean put(Collection<? extends E1> e1, int[] variation1, Collection<? extends E2> e2, int[] variation2)
263    {
264        if(e1 == null || e2 == null) return false;
265        int len = elements1.size;
266        elements1.putAll(e1);
267        for (int i = len; i < elements1.size; i++) {
268            mm1.add(new IntVLA(4));
269        }
270        len = elements2.size;
271        elements2.putAll(e2);
272        for (int i = len; i < elements2.size; i++) {
273            mm2.add(new IntVLA(4));
274        }
275        int[][] bundle1, bundle2;
276        if(variation1 == null)
277            bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)};
278        else
279            bundle1 = new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1), variation1};
280        if(variation2 == null)
281            bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2)};
282        else
283            bundle2 = new int[][]{elements2.getArray(e2), variation2};
284        if(!bm.put(bundle1, bundle2))
285            return false;
286        len = e1.size();
287        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
288            mm1.get(bundle1[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
289        }
290        len = e2.size();
291        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
292            mm2.get(bundle2[0][i]).add(bm.size()-1);
293        }
294        return true;
295    }
296
297    /**
298     * Puts all unique E1 and E2 keys in {@code aKeys} and {@code bKeys} into this K2 at the end. If an E1 in aKeys or a E2
299     * in bKeys is already present when this would add one, this will not put the E1 and E2 keys at that point in the
300     * iteration order, and will place the next unique E1 and E2 it finds in the arguments at that position instead.
301     * @param aKeys an Iterable or Collection of E1 keys to add; should all be unique (like a Set)
302     * @param bKeys an Iterable or Collection of E2 keys to add; should all be unique (like a Set)
303     * @return true if this collection changed as a result of this call
304     */
305    public boolean putAll(Iterable<? extends Collection<? extends E1>> aKeys, Iterable<? extends Collection<? extends E2>> bKeys)
306    {
307        if(aKeys == null || bKeys == null) return false;
308        Iterator<? extends Collection<? extends E1>> aIt = aKeys.iterator();
309        Iterator<? extends Collection<? extends E2>> bIt = bKeys.iterator();
310        boolean changed = false;
311        while (aIt.hasNext() && bIt.hasNext())
312        {
313            changed = put(aIt.next(), bIt.next()) || changed;
314        }
315        return changed;
316    }
317    /**
318     * Puts all unique E1 and E2 keys in {@code other} into this K2, respecting other's ordering. If an E1 or a E2 in other
319     * is already present when this would add one, this will not put the E1 and E2 keys at that point in the iteration
320     * order, and will place the next unique E1 and E2 it finds in the arguments at that position instead.
321     * @param other another K2 collection with the same E1 and E2 types
322     * @return true if this collection changed as a result of this call
323     */
324    public boolean putAll(BundleBundleBiMap<? extends E1, ? extends E2> other)
325    {
326        if(other == null) return false;
327        boolean changed = false;
328        int sz = other.size();
329        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
330            int[][] bundle1 = other.bm.getAAt(i), bundle2 = other.bm.getBAt(i);
331            if(bundle1 == null || bundle1.length == 0 || bundle2 == null || bundle2.length == 0) continue;
332            if(bundle1.length == 1 && bundle2.length == 1)
333            {
334                changed |= put(elements1.keysAt(bundle1[0]), elements2.keysAt(bundle2[0]));
335            }
336            else
337            {
338                changed |= put(elements1.keysAt(bundle1[0]), bundle1.length > 1 ? bundle1[1] : null,
339                        elements2.keysAt(bundle2[0]), bundle2.length > 1 ? bundle2[1] : null);
340            }
341        }
342        return changed;
343    }
344
345    /**
346     * Given an index to look up, gets a 2D int array representing the bundle at that index. The bundle is likely to
347     * use a representation for the first sub-array that will be meaningless without internal information from this
348     * BundleBiMap, but the second sub-array, if present, should match the variation supplied with that bundle
349     * to {@link #put(Object[], int[], Object[], int[])} or {@link #put(Collection, int[], Collection, int[])}.
350     * <br>
351     * This method copies the 2D int array it returns, so modifying it won't affect the original BundleBiMap.
352     * @param index an int index to look up
353     * @return a 2D int array that represents a bundle, or null if index is out of bounds
354     */
355    public int[][] getCodeAt(int index)
356    {
357        return ArrayTools.copy(bm.getAAt(index));
358    }
359    /**
360     * Given an index to look up, gets the E2 key present at that position in the ordering.
361     * @param index an int index to look up
362     */
363    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2At(int index)
364    {
365        return elements2.keysAt(bm.getBAt(index)[0]);
366    }
367
368    /**
369     * Given a bundle of E1 keys as an array with no variation, gets the matching E2 key for that bundle, or null if there
370     * is none.
371     * @param e1 an array of E1
372     * @return the E2 keys that correspond to the given bundle, e1 combined with variations
373     */
374    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2(E1[] e1)
375    {
376        if(e1 == null) return null;
377        return elements2.keysAt(bm.getBFromA(new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)})[0]);
378    }
379
380
381    /**
382     * Given a bundle of E1 keys as an array with an int array variation, gets the matching E2 key for that bundle, or
383     * null if there is none.
384     * @param e1 an array of E1 element keys
385     * @param variations an int array that should match an int array used as a variation parameter to put
386     * @return the E2 keys that correspond to the given bundle, e1 combined with variations
387     */
388    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2(E1[] e1, int[] variations)
389    {
390        if(e1 == null || variations == null) return null;
391        return elements2.keysAt(bm.getBFromA(new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1), variations})[0]);
392    }
393
394    /**
395     * Given a bundle of E1 keys as a Collection with no variation, gets the matching E2 key for that bundle, or
396     * null if there is none.
397     * @param e1 a Collection of E1 element keys (each key can be an E1 or an instance of any subclass of E1)
398     * @return the E2 key that corresponds to the given bundle, e
399     */
400    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2(Collection<? extends E1> e1)
401    {
402        if(e1 == null) return null;
403        return elements2.keysAt(bm.getBFromA(new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1)})[0]);
404    }
405
406    /**
407     * Given a bundle of E1 keys as a Collection with an int array variation, gets the matching E2 key for that bundle, or
408     * null if there is none.
409     * @param e1 a Collection of E1 element keys (each key can be an E1 or an instance of any subclass of E1)
410     * @param variations an int array that should match an int array used as a variation parameter to put
411     * @return the E2 key that corresponds to the given bundle, e1 combined with variations
412     */
413    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2(Collection<? extends E1> e1, int[] variations)
414    {
415        if(e1 == null || variations == null) return null;
416        return elements2.keysAt(bm.getBFromA(new int[][]{elements1.getArray(e1), variations})[0]);
417    }
418    /**
419     * Given an E1 bundle as a coded 2D int array, gets the matching E2 bundle, also coded, or null if there is none.
420     * The code parameter should be obtained from one of the methods that specifically returns that kind of 2D array,
421     * since the code uses internal information to efficiently represent a bundle.
422     * @param code a 2D int array representing a bundle that should have been obtained directly from this object
423     * @return the E2 key that corresponds to the given coded bundle
424     */
425    public int[][] getElement2Coded(int[][] code)
426    {
427        if(code == null) return null;
428        return bm.getBFromA(code);
429    }
430
431    /**
432     * Gets (in near-constant time) the index of the given E2 coded key in the ordering.
433     * @param code a E2 coded key to look up
434     * @return the position in the ordering of code
435     */
436    public int indexOfElement2Coded(int[][] code)
437    {
438        return bm.indexOfB(code);
439    }
440
441    /**
442     * Given a coded bundle as produced by some methods in this class, decodes the elements1 part of the bundle and
443     * returns it as a newly-allocated OrderedSet of E1 element keys.
444     * @param bundle a coded bundle as a 2D int array
445     * @return an OrderedSet of E1 element keys corresponding to the data coded into bundle
446     */
447    public OrderedSet<E1> elementsFromCode(int[][] bundle)
448    {
449        if(bundle == null || bundle.length < 1 || bundle[0] == null) return null;
450        return elements1.keysAt(bundle[0]);
451    }
452
453    /**
454     * Given a coded bundle as produced by some methods in this class, decodes the variation part of the bundle, if
455     * present, and returns it as a newly-allocated 1D int array. If there is no variation in the given coded bundle,
456     * this returns null.
457     * @param bundle a coded bundle as a 2D int array
458     * @return the variation part of the data coded into bundle
459     */
460    public int[] variationFromCode(int[][] bundle)
461    {
462        if(bundle == null || bundle.length < 2 || bundle[1] == null) return null;
463        int[] ret = new int[bundle[1].length];
464        System.arraycopy(bundle[1], 0, ret, 0, ret.length);
465        return ret;
466    }
467
468    /**
469     * Given an E2 key to look up, gets a (newly-allocated) OrderedSet of E1 element keys corresponding to that E2 key.
470     * If a variation is part of the bundle, it will not be present in this, but a copy can be retrieved with
471     * {@link #getElement1BundleVariation(Object[])}.
472     * @param lookup a E2 key to look up
473     * @return an OrderedSet of the E1 elements1 used in the bundle that corresponds to single, or null if invalid
474     */
475    public OrderedSet<E1> getBundleElements(E2[] lookup)
476    {
477        int[][] bundle;
478        if(lookup == null || (bundle = bm.getAFromB(new int[][]{elements2.getArray(lookup)})) == null
479                || bundle.length < 1 || bundle[0] == null) return null;
480        return elements1.keysAt(bundle[0]);
481    }
482
483    /**
484     * Given an E2 key to look up, gets a (newly-allocated) int array that is equivalent to the variation part of the
485     * bundle corresponding to single. If there is no variation in the corresponding bundle, then this returns null.
486     * To get the E1 elements1 that are the main part of a bundle, you can use {@link #getBundleElements(Object[])}.
487     * @param lookup a bundle of E2 keys to look up
488     * @return the variation part of the E1 bundle that corresponds to the looked-up bundle, or null if invalid
489     */
490    public int[] getElement1BundleVariation(E2[] lookup)
491    {
492        int[][] bundle;
493        if(lookup == null || (bundle = bm.getAFromB(new int[][]{elements2.getArray(lookup)})) == null
494                || bundle.length < 2 || bundle[1] == null) return null;
495        int[] ret = new int[bundle[1].length];
496        System.arraycopy(bundle[1], 0, ret, 0, ret.length);
497        return ret;
498    }
499
500    /**
501     * Given an index to look up, gets a (newly-allocated) OrderedSet of E1 element keys in the bundle at that index.
502     * If a variation is part of the bundle, it will not be present in this, but a copy can be retrieved with
503     * {@link #getBundleVariationAt(int)}.
504     * @param index an int position in the ordering to look up
505     * @return an OrderedSet of the E1 elements1 used in the bundle present at index, or null if invalid
506     */
507    public OrderedSet<E1> getBundleElementsAt(int index)
508    {
509        int[][] bundle;
510        if((bundle = bm.getAAt(index)) == null || bundle.length < 1) return null;
511        return elements1.keysAt(bundle[0]);
512    }
513    /**
514     * Given an index to look up, gets a (newly-allocated) int array that is equivalent to the variation part of the
515     * bundle present at that index. If there is no variation in the corresponding bundle, then this returns null.
516     * To get the E1 elements1 that are the main part of a bundle, you can use {@link #getBundleElementsAt(int)}.
517     * @param index an int position in the ordering to look up
518     * @return an int array copied from the variation part of the bundle present at index, or null if invalid
519     */
520    public int[] getBundleVariationAt(int index)
521    {
522        int[][] bundle;
523        if((bundle = bm.getAAt(index)) == null || bundle.length < 2 || bundle[1] == null) return null;
524        int[] ret = new int[bundle[1].length];
525        System.arraycopy(bundle[1], 0, ret, 0, ret.length);
526        return ret;
527    }
528
529    /**
530     * Given an E1 element key that could be used in one or more bundles this uses, finds all E2 single keys corresponding
531     * to bundles that contain the given element. Thus, if E1 was String and this BundleBiMap contained ["Copper", "Tin"]
532     * mapped to "Bronze" and ["Zinc", "Copper"] mapped to "Brass", then calling this method with "Copper" would get an
533     * OrderedSet that contains ["Bronze", "Brass"].
534     * @param element an E1 element key to look up (probably a component of one or more bundles)
535     * @return an OrderedSet of all E2 keys where the given element is part of the bundle corresponding to that E2 key, or null if E1 does not match anything
536     */
537    public OrderedSet<OrderedSet<? extends E2>> getManyElement2(E1 element)
538    {
539        if(element == null) return null;
540        int pos;
541        if((pos = elements1.getInt(element)) < 0) return null;
542
543        IntVLA positions = mm1.get(pos);
544        OrderedSet<OrderedSet<? extends E2>> ks = new OrderedSet<>(positions.size);
545        for(int i = 0; i < positions.size; i++)
546        {
547            ks.add(getElement2At(positions.get(i)));
548        }
549        return ks;
550    }
551    /**
552     * Given an E1 element key that could be used in one or more bundles this uses, gets all bundles in this object that
553     * contain the given element, as coded 2D int arrays. These coded bundles can be given to
554     * {@link #elementsFromCode(int[][])} and {@link #variationFromCode(int[][])} to get usable information from them.
555     * @param element an E1 element key to look up (probably a component of one or more bundles)
556     * @return an OrderedSet of all coded 2D int array bundles that contain the given element, or null if E1 is not in any bundles
557     */
558    public OrderedSet<int[][]> getManyCoded(E1 element)
559    {
560        if(element == null) return null;
561        int pos;
562        if((pos = elements1.getInt(element)) < 0) return null;
563        return bm.keysA.keysAt(mm1.get(pos));
564    }
565
566    /**
567     * Given an E1 element key that could be used in one or more bundles this uses, gets all indices in the ordering
568     * that contain a bundle with that element.  From such an index, you can use {@link #getElement2At(int)} (int)} to get the
569     * E2 key at that position, {@link #getBundleElementsAt(int)} to get the E1 element keys at that position,
570     * {@link #getBundleVariationAt(int)} to get the possible variation at that position, or {@link #getCodeAt(int)} to
571     * get the coded bundle at that position.
572     * @return an OrderedSet of all coded 2D int array bundles that contain the given element, or null if E1 is not in any bundles
573     */
574    public int[] getManyIndices(E1 element)
575    {
576        if(element == null) return null;
577        int pos;
578        if((pos = elements1.getInt(element)) < 0) return null;
579        return mm1.get(pos).toArray();
580    }
581
582    /**
583     * Reorders this BundleBiMap using {@code ordering}, which has the same length as this object's {@link #size()}
584     * and can be generated with {@link ArrayTools#range(int)} (which, if applied, would produce no
585     * change to the current ordering), {@link IRNG#randomOrdering(int)} (which gives a random ordering, and if
586     * applied immediately would be the same as calling {@link #shuffle(IRNG)}), or made in some other way. If you
587     * already have an ordering and want to make a different ordering that can undo the change, you can use
588     * {@link ArrayTools#invertOrdering(int[])} called on the original ordering. The effects of this method, if called
589     * with an ordering that has repeat occurrences of an int or contains ints that are larger than its size should
590     * permit, are undefined other than the vague definition of "probably bad, unless you like crashes."
591     * @param ordering an int array or vararg that must contain each int from 0 to {@link #size()}
592     * @return this for chaining
593     */
594    public BundleBundleBiMap<E1, E2> reorder(int... ordering)
595    {
596        if(ordering == null || ordering.length != bm.size()) return this;
597        bm.reorder(ordering);
598        int len = mm1.size();
599        for (int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
600            IntVLA iv = mm1.get(i);
601            for (int j = 0; j < iv.size; j++) {
602                iv.set(i, ordering[iv.get(i)]);
603            }
604        }
605        return this;
606    }
607
608    /**
609     * Generates a random ordering with rng and applies the same ordering to all kinds of keys this has; they will
610     * maintain their current association to other keys but their ordering/indices will change.
611     * @param rng an IRNG to produce the random ordering this will use
612     * @return this for chaining
613     */
614    public BundleBundleBiMap<E1, E2> shuffle(IRNG rng)
615    {
616        return reorder(rng.randomOrdering(bm.size()));
617    }
618
619    /**
620     * Creates a new iterator over the individual E1 element keys this holds, with a larger total count the iterator may
621     * yield than {@link #size()} in most cases (it should be equal to {@link #elementSize()}), and in no particular
622     * order (though the order should be stable across versions and platforms, no special means are provided to further
623     * control the order). The E1 keys are individual, not bundled, and duplicate keys should never be encountered even
624     * if an E1 key appears in many bundles.
625     * @return a newly-created iterator over this BundleBiMap's individual (non-bundled) E1 keys
626     */
627    public Iterator<E1> iteratorElement1()
628    {
629        return elements1.iterator();
630    }
631    /**
632     * Creates a new iterator over the E2 single keys this holds. The total number of items this yields should be equal
633     * to {@link #size()}. This method can be problematic for garbage collection if called very frequently; it may be
634     * better to access items by index (which also lets you access other keys associated with that index) using
635     * {@link #getElement2At(int)} in a for(int i=0...) loop.
636     * @return a newly-created iterator over this BundleBiMap's E2 keys
637     */
638    public Iterator<E2> iteratorElement2()
639    {
640        return elements2.iterator();
641    }
642
643    /**
644     * Gets and caches the individual E1 keys as a Collection that implements SortedSet (and so also implements Set).
645     * @return the E1 keys as a SortedSet
646     */
647    public SortedSet<E1> getElement1Set() {
648        return elements1.keySet();
649    }
650
651    /**
652     * Gets and caches the E2 single keys as a Collection that implements SortedSet (and so also implements Set).
653     * @return the E2 keys as a SortedSet
654     */
655    public SortedSet<E2> getElement2Set() {
656        return elements2.keySet();
657    }
658
659    /**
660     * To be called sparingly, since this allocates a new OrderedSet instead of reusing one.
661     * @return the E1 keys as an OrderedSet
662     */
663    public OrderedSet<E1> getElement1OrderedSet() {
664        return elements1.keysAsOrderedSet();
665    }
666
667    /**
668     * To be called sparingly, since this allocates a new OrderedSet instead of reusing one.
669     * @return the E2 keys as an OrderedSet
670     */
671    public OrderedSet<E2> getElement2OrderedSet() {
672        return elements2.keysAsOrderedSet();
673    }
674
675    /**
676     * Gets the total number of bundle-to-single pairs in this BundleBiMap.
677     * @return the total number of bundle keys (equivalently, the number of single keys) in this object
678     */
679    public int size() {
680        return bm.size();
681    }
682
683    /**
684     * Gets the total number of unique E1 element keys across all bundles in this BundleBiMap. Usually not the same as
685     * {@link #size()}, and ordinarily a fair amount larger, though this can also be smaller.
686     * @return the total number of unique E1 element keys in all bundles this contains
687     */
688    public int elementSize() {
689        return elements1.size();
690    }
691
692    public boolean isEmpty()
693    {
694        return bm.isEmpty();
695    }
696
697}
